incorrect try again try again try again try again try again try again that is incorrect. click here to learn the answer, then come back to try again. review the features of stomach. identify the: tas k body greater curvature lesser curvature cardia cardial notch fundus pylorus (inc. pyloric antrum and canal ) pyloric orifice and sphincter identify the: tas k open the stomach and inspect its internal surface. rugae rugae are longitudinal folds of the gastric mucosa and submucosa. they flatten out as the stomach fills, and thus function to permit expansion and increased volume as needed. moisten the specimen and cover it with a damp cloth; it needs to be handy for your progress check. unwrap the specimen marked “stomach”. lay it out on a table. the pylorus the pyloris connects the body of the stomach to the duodenum. the pyloric antrum is that part adjacent to the body that narrows rapidly into the more cylindrical pyloric canal. correct that's right! rugae disappear as the stomach fills. continue continue continue continue continue continue 1. what are the features of the internal surface of the stomach that flatten with stomach filling to increase its volume? 11.2 quiz submit

incorrect try again try again try again try again try again try again that is incorrect. click here to learn the answer, then come back to try again. systemic veins drain into the svc or ivc. systemic veins are thus, sometimes, called “caval” veins. examples are the veins draining the head and neck, limbs and body wall. pulmonary veins drain the lungs. veins of the hepatic portal system (“portal veins”) drain the digestive tract first to the liver, and only after processing in this organ, does the venous blood then drain into the ivc. in this way, portal veins are distinct from systemic veins. as illustrated, portal veins respect the division of the digestive tract into the foregut, midgut and hindgut. the hindgut is drained by the inferior mesenteric vein. the midgut is drained by the superior mesenteric vein. the foregut is drained by a combination of vessels that includes the splenic vein, the gastric veins and the gastro-omental veins. all of these veins ultimately combine to form the hepatic portal vein, which runs in the hepatoduodenal ligament and drains into the liver at the porta hepatis. correct that's right! caval veins drain into the svc or ivc. continue continue continue continue continue continue 2. systemic veins drain into the svc or ivc, and thus are often referred to as _____________________ veins. 11.2 quiz submit

incorrect try again try again try again try again try again try again that is incorrect. click here to learn the answer, then come back to try again. uncover the liver with the attached diaphragm. tas k identify the right and left lobes, covered by visceral peritoneum. identify the falciform ligament, formed as the serous membrane reflects off the right and left lobes and onto the underside of the diaphragm. follow the falciform ligament to the point where its two laminae diverge to place one hand on each of the anterior and posterior surfaces of the left lobe. as you slide your hands up toward the diaphragm to touch the left coronary ligament, you’ll find your hands are close together. repeat this with the right lobe, and you will find that when you touch the right coronary ligament, your hands are quite far apart! the surface of the liver between your hands is directly attached to the underside of the diaphragm. it is therefore not covered by visceral peritoneum. this is the bare area of the liver, largely located on the superior surface of the right lobe. form the right and left coronary ligaments which attach the liver to the underside of the diaphragm. correct that's right! the right and left coronary ligaments attach the liver to the underside of the diaphragm. continue continue continue continue continue continue 3. the liver is attached to the underside of the diaphragm by the right and left _____________________ ligaments. 11.2 quiz submit

incorrect try again try again try again try again try again try again that is incorrect. click here to learn the answer, then come back to try again. on the posterior aspect of the diaphragmatic surface, identify the bare area. this surface was fixed by ct to the inferior surface of the diaphragm, and thus is not covered by visceral peritoneum. around the bare area, note the cut edges of the coronary ligaments, which form the margins note the sharp anterior border of the liver that separates the diaphragmatic surface from the visceral surface. on the visceral surface, note the h-shaped structures and creases that separate the four anatomical lobes of the liver; identify the right lobe, left lobe, caudate lobe and quadrate lobe. uncover the isolated liver without the diaphragm. tas k of the bare area. identify the lateral extensions of the coronary ligaments, which are the right and left triangular ligaments. correct that's right! the bare area is in direct contact with the underside of the diaphragm and is bound to it by ct. continue continue continue continue continue continue 4. the only surface of the liver not covered by visceral peritoneum is its ____________ ____________, where connective tissue binds the liver to the underside of the diaphragm. 11.2 quiz submit

incorrect try again try again try again try again try again try again that is incorrect. click here to learn the answer, then come back to try again. the fetal circulation this diagram, from an early edition of gray’s anatomy, shows the fetal circulation, and explains the formation of both the round ligament of the liver and the ligamentum venosum. the round ligament of the liver is a remnant of the umbilical vein, which carried oxygenated blood from the placenta, through the umbilicus, to the fetal liver. it is located in the free edge of the falciform ligament. the ductus venosus collected blood from the umbilical vein and carried it to the ivc, which delivered it to the right atrium. postnatally, the ductus venosus degenerates, forming the ligamentum venosum, which you see on the visceral surface of the liver under study. correct that's right! the ductus venosus degenerates postnatally, forming the ligamentum venosum. continue continue continue continue continue continue 5. the ligamentum venosum is a remnant of the ____________ ____________, which carried fetal blood from the umbilical vein to the inferior vena cava. 11.2 quiz submit

incorrect try again try again try again try again try again try again that is incorrect. click here to learn the answer, then come back to try again. identify, in the specimen of the gastroduodenal junction, tas k the pylorus, pyloric sphincter, the major duodenal papilla and the plicae circulares. the hepatopancreatic ampulla opens into the duodenum at the major duodenal papilla. uncover the three segments of small intestine. lay the specimens out so that you can compare them. the papilla is formed by a ring of smooth muscle, the hepatopancreatic sphincter , which controls the flow of bile and pancreatic juice into the duodenum. a.k.a. the ampulla of vater a.k.a. the sphincter of oddi plicae circulares are transverse folds of mucosa and submucosa. they are permanent, and do not flatten out as the lumen fills, as is the case with the rugae of the stomach. their purpose is different from that of rugae of the stomach; the plicae circulares are found only in the small intestine and function to increase surface area for nutrient absorption. plicae circulares “circular folds” correct that's right! the hepatopancreatic sphincter, also known as the sphincter of oddi, underlies the duodenal papilla and controls bile secretion into the duodenum. continue continue continue continue continue continue 6. the major duodenal papilla is formed by a ring of smooth muscle, the ____________ ____________, which controls the emptying of the hepatopancreatic ampulla. 11.2 quiz submit

incorrect try again try again try again try again try again try again that is incorrect. click here to learn the answer, then come back to try again. compare the plicae circulares in the three specimens. tas k you might be able to notice with the naked eye that they are tallest and most tightly-packed in the jejunum. this is logical; the plicae circulares increase surface area for nutrient absorption. the majority of nutrient absorption occurs in the jejunum because of its greater surface area per unit length. surface area is maximized in the jejunum not only because of its tall, tightly-packed plicae circulares; as explained in the emodule on the histology of the digestive tract, microscopic features that increase surface area, the villi and microvilli, are also most well-developed in the jejunum. in the specimen of the ileocecal junction (right), identify the ileocecal sphincter by feel. visually identify the ileocecal fold flaps. identify the cecum, defined as that portion of the ascending colon inferior to the ileocecal junction. finally, identify the appendix. moisten these specimens and cover them with a damp cloth. correct that's right! the plicae circulares are tallest in the jejunum. the plicae increase surface area for nutrient absorption, most of which takes place in the jejunum. continue continue continue continue continue continue 7. in which subdivision of the small intestine are the plicae circulares tallest? 11.2 quiz submit

incorrect try again try again try again try again try again try again that is incorrect. click here to learn the answer, then come back to try again. unwrap the specimen of the spleen. tas k identify its convex diaphragmatic surface, marked by costal impressions, and its irregular, concave visceral surface. distinguish its sharp anterior border from its rounded posterior border . on the visceral surface of the spleen, identify its hilum, containing splenic arteries and veins. notice the contact impressions made by adjacent organs. the spleen is a left-sided organ lying adjacent to the 9th - 11th ribs. it is largely located between the fundus of the stomach and the diaphragm. only when enlarged can the spleen be palpated inferior to the costal margin. like the lungs! you might recall that each lung has a sharp anterior border that occupies the costomediastinal recess, and a rounded posterior border formed by contact with the vertebral bodies and the angle of the ribs the gastric impression is the largest and most anterior, formed by the fundus of the stomach. the renal impression is posterior, and is made by the superior pole of the left kidney. the colic impression is formed by the left (splenic) flexure of the large intestine. the pancreatic impression is formed by the tail of the pancreas contacting its visceral surface inferior to the hilum. moisten the specimen and cover it with a damp cloth. correct that's right! the spleen lies on the left side, largely between fundus of the stomach and the diaphragm, and adjacent to the 9th to 11th ribs. continue continue continue continue continue continue 8. the spleen is a left-sided organ that lies adjacent to the ____th to ____th ribs. 11.2 quiz submit
